results.title: Hand-coloured film
results.brief_description: It’s estimated that about 80% of films made between the 1890s and the 1920s were coloured through tinting, toning, stencilling and hand-colouring. This process helped bring vibrancy and beauty to fluttering butterfly wings, hypnotic dances and much more.

constellations_primary.name: Colour and creativity
constellations_primary.description: From dying film to Technicolor and beyond, creative applications of colour have been part of cinema since its inception.

results.description: Think the beginning of cinema was all black and white? Think again. Artists have been colouring films since films were invented. It’s estimated that about 80% of films made between the 1890s and the 1920s were coloured through tinting, toning, stencilling and hand-colouring. This work was done from the mid-1890s by colourists like Elisabeth Thuillier. Thuillier employed 200 women in her Paris workshop, where they worked on a production line and each painted one colour on a film. This process helped bring vibrancy and beauty to fluttering butterfly wings, hypnotic dances and much more.
description_for_label: Think the beginning of cinema was all black and white? Think again. Artists have been colouring films since films were invented. It’s estimated that about 80% of films made between the 1890s and the 1920s were coloured through tinting, toning, stencilling and hand-colouring. This work was done from the mid-1890s by colourists like Elisabeth Thuillier. Thuillier employed 200 women in her Paris workshop, where they worked on a production line and each painted one colour on a film. This process helped bring vibrancy and beauty to fluttering butterfly wings, hypnotic dances and much more.

display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Pictures → MI-02. Play and Illusion → MI-02-C01 → Panel C5

results.title: 'Tank Man' protestor, Tiananmen Square
results.brief_description: ‘An unknown man stared down a column of tanks the morning after the Chinese government massacred pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in 1989. His fate and identity remain unknown, but the moment – captured on film and smuggled to safety – has become a symbol of defiance.

constellations_primary.name: Uncovering the truth
constellations_primary.description: The images of Tank Man during the Tiananmen Square protests in 1989 were captured by photojournalists and shared around the world. The work of journalists has been key to uncovering abuses of power and are rich material for fictional and factual movies and TV.

constellations_other.name: Spectacle
constellations_other.description: The moving image has captured some of history’s biggest moments. From newsreel shorts in cinemas before the show to the arrival of TV, nightly news and the 24-hour news cycle to social media, news has become a spectacle.

results.description: ‘An unknown man stared down a column of tanks the morning after the Chinese government massacred pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in 1989. His fate and identity remain unknown, but the moment – captured on film and smuggled to safety – has become a symbol of defiance.

His fate and identity remain unknown, but the moment – captured on film and smuggled to safety – has become a symbol of defiance.

results.title: #TeenageDirtbag challenge
results.material_description: digital screen recording of @parishilton's TikTok post
results.brief_description: Over 20 years since Wheatus released their song ‘Teenage Dirtbag’ its nostalgic allure is still as potent as ever. The “Teenage dirtbag” challenge has been popularized by users and celebrities alike, including Paris Hilton, Christina Aguilera and Tara Reid. Compiling photos from adolescence in the early 2000’ to the Wheatus song. Think emo, myspace, American Pie and of course Paris Hilton. Like most viral trends there has been a divide between younger gen z and the millennials who were actually around for the period, dubbed “Indie Sleeze”
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Over 20 years since Wheatus released ‘Teenage Dirtbag’, its nostalgic allure remains as potent as ever. The “Teenage Dirtbag” challenge, which sees people compile photos of their early 2000s adolescence to the song, has been popularised by everyday users and celebrities alike, including Paris Hilton, Christina Aguilera and Tara Reid. Think emo, MySpace, American Pie and, of course, Paris Hilton. Like most viral trends there’s been a divide between younger Gen Z and the Millennials who were actually around for the “Indie Sleeze” period.
description_for_label: Over 20 years since Wheatus released their song ‘Teenage Dirtbag’ its nostalgic allure is still as potent as ever. The “Teenage dirtbag” challenge has been popularised by users and celebrities alike, including Paris Hilton, Christina Aguilera and Tara Reid. Compiling photos from adolescence in the early 2000s to the Wheatus song. Think emo, MySpace, American Pie and of course Paris Hilton. Like most viral trends there has been a divide between younger Gen Z and the Millennials who were actually around for the period dubbed “Indie Sleeze”.

results.title: Chris Pine disassociating
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Where to start with the premiere of Don’t Worry Darling? The feud between director and star? The leaked texts? Harry Styles seemingly spitting on Chris Pine? By then, Pine had already checked out after enduring co-star Styles praising the cinematic quality of ‘the movie’. All viral moments, but Pine’s dead stare recalls the Sad Affleck meme and can be reused to have his mental retreat express our own, which we may need since Styles’ bumbling also seemed to represent an existential threat to cinema in the streaming age of IP-driven blockbusters, which many hoped ‘the movie’ would defy.
description_for_label: Where to start with the premiere of Don’t Worry Darling. The feud between director and star? The leaked texts? Harry Styles seemingly spitting on Chris Pine? By then, Pine had already checked out after enduring co-star Styles praising the cinematic quality of ‘the movie’. All viral moments, but Pine’s dead stare recalls the Sad Affleck meme and can be reused to have his mental retreat express our own, which we may need since Styles’ bumbling also somehow came off like an existential threat to cinema. Ironic, since many expected ‘the movie’ to be a hit that defied streaming and IP-driven blockbusters.

display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: Remembering Uncle Jack Charles
results.material_description: Digital screen recording of a @NITV Tiktok of Uncle Jack Charles' speech accepting the National NAIDOC Male Elder Award in 2022.
results.brief_description:
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people should be aware that this video contains the name, image and voice of a deceased person.
ACMI mourns the passing of actor, musician and revered Aboriginal Elder, Uncle Jack Charles. The Boon Wurrung, Dja Dja Wurrung, Woiwurrung and Yorta Yorta “father of Black theatre” passed away aged 79.
In addition to his monumental contribution to theatre, film and music, Charles was a survivor of the Stolen Generations, and advocated tirelessly for the rights of incarcerated Indigenous people.
In 2022 he was awarded the National NAIDOC Male Elder Award, giving an acceptance speech that reflects his lifetime of staunch advocacy.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people should be aware that this video contains the name, image and voice of a deceased person.

Revered actor, musician and revered Aboriginal Elder, Uncle Jack Charles has sadly passed aged 79. The Boon Wurrung, Dja Dja Wurrung, Woiwurrung and Yorta Yorta “father of Black theatre” made a monumental contribution to theatre, film and music. He was a survivor of the Stolen Generations and advocated tirelessly for Indigenous rights, reflected in his acceptance speech for the 2022 National NAIDOC Male Elder Award.
description_for_label:
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people should be aware that this video contains the name, image and voice of a deceased person.

Revered actor, musician and revered Aboriginal Elder, Uncle Jack Charles has sadly passed aged 79. The Boon Wurrung, Dja Dja Wurrung, Woiwurrung and Yorta Yorta “father of Black theatre” made a monumental contribution to theatre, film and music. He was a survivor of the Stolen Generations and advocated tirelessly for Indigenous rights, reflected in his acceptance speech for 2022 the National NAIDOC Male Elder Award.

results.title: Another day, another Emmanuel don’t do it
results.brief_description: TikTok’s newest cute animal to become a viral sensation is an attention-seeking emu named Emmanuel from @KnuckleBumpFarms, a small hobby farm in Florida. Emmanuel’s most famous antics involve disrupting his owner, the influencer Taylor Blake, as she attempts to film content for her 2M followers. Blake runs the farm with her girlfriend Kristian Haggerty, who was previously one half of the first LGBT+ couple to appear on reality show The Bachelor in Paradise.
results.title_for_label: Another day, another Emmanuel don’t do it
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

TikTok’s newest cute animal to become a viral sensation is an attention-seeking emu named Emmanuel from @KnuckleBumpFarms, a small hobby farm in Florida. Emmanuel’s most famous antics involve disrupting his owner, the influencer Taylor Blake, as she attempts to film content for her 2M followers. Blake runs the farm with her girlfriend Kristian Haggerty, who was previously one half of the first LGBT+ couple to appear on reality show The Bachelor in Paradise.

results.title: Sue Ford Moving Image Collection
results.brief_description:
The Sue Ford Moving Image Collection contains the film and video work of Australian artist Sue Ford (1943–2009). The collection includes complete films made during the 1970s and 1980s, including “Faces”, “Time changes” and “Egami”, as well as an extensive archive of 8mm home movies, documentary footage, offcuts, and process-based experiments.

Sue Ford is one of Australia’s pre-eminent photographers and experimental filmmakers. Establishing her photographic practice in the late 1960s, she was the first woman photographer to hold a solo exhibition at the National Gallery of Victoria in 1974. She was a key figure in Melbourne’s art scene throughout the 1970s, where she was involved with the Women’s Art Group alongside artists such as Bonita Ely and Micky Allan. After a time spent in Sydney where she was involved with the Sydney Filmmakers Cooperative, she became a founding member of the feminist film collective Reel Women in the late 1970s.

Most of her films were created during this period and she continued to make photographic and multimedia work throughout the 1990s and 2000s. Her work is held in the collection of the National Gallery of Victoria, the Art Gallery of New South Wales, the Art Gallery of Western Australia, and the National Gallery of Australia.

The Sue Ford Moving Image Collection has been generously donated to ACMI by the Sue Ford Archive, co-directed by her son, Ben Ford, and friend, Joy Hirst.
